title: Targeting Obama, Trump’s Retribution Campaign Takes Another Turn
summary: After focusing his second-term ire on other individuals and institutions, President Trump is again seeking prosecution of his most prominent rivals — this time with aides more inclined to carry out his wishes.

title: U.S. Quietly Drafts Plan to End Program That Saved Millions From AIDS
summary: PEPFAR, the campaign to end H.I.V. globally, would morph into an effort to detect disease outbreaks and sell American products, according to documents obtained by The Times.

title: American Convicted of Murder Among Those Trump Rescued From Venezuela Prison
summary: The Trump administration said it was protecting Americans unjustly held abroad. One of the rescued men, Dahud Hanid Ortiz, killed three people, according to court documents.

title: Trump Administration Plans to Give A.I. Developers a Free Hand
summary: In an “A.I. Action Plan,” the White House outlined steps it said would promote American dominance in the fast-growing technology.

title: Aid Groups Blame Israel’s Gaza Restrictions for ‘Mass Starvation’
summary: More than 100 organizations, including Save the Children and Doctors Without Borders, added to growing calls for aid restrictions to be eased and the war to end.

title: Ozzy Osbourne’s Death Draws Mourners, Including Drake, to the ‘Home of Heavy Metal’
summary: In Birmingham, England, the singer’s hometown, fans paid tribute by leaving flowers, beer and tequila. The rapper Drake was there to pay his respects, too.

title: Biting a Bat and 5 Other Wild Moments From Ozzy Osbourne’s Life
summary: Alcohol and drugs were often involved in funny, bizarre and terrible incidents in the heavy metal legend’s long career.

title: Deferring to Trump, Senate Pulls Back on New Russia Sanctions
summary: Republican leaders said they were ready to vote as soon as this month on punishing penalties against Moscow but have paused after President Trump threatened to act unilaterally within weeks.

title: Zelensky Faces Criticism in Ukraine Over Effort to Rein In Corruption Agencies
summary: President Volodymyr Zelensky signed a bill limiting two Ukrainian anticorruption agencies. After street protests and other criticism, he said he would propose a new law restoring their independence.

title: With Russia and Ukraine to Meet Again, Here’s What to Know About the Peace Talks
summary: The warring sides are still far apart heading into the third round of U.S.-brokered peace negotiations, set for Wednesday in Istanbul.

title: How Japan Clinched a Trade Deal With Trump Just Days Ahead of the Tariff Deadline
summary: After months of fraught negotiations with the United States, Japan clinched a deal just days before punitive tariffs were scheduled to take effect.

title: As Trump Quits UNESCO, China Expands Influence
summary: Washington had been a buffer against China’s efforts to use UNESCO to influence education, historical designations and even artificial intelligence.

title: What to Know About the U.S. Move to Withdraw From UNESCO
summary: The Trump administration plans to pull out of the U.N. cultural agency, putting UNESCO back at the center of geopolitical rivalry.

title: Chinese Hackers Are Exploiting Flaws in Widely Used Software, Microsoft Says
summary: The company said state-backed hacking groups were breaching systems through flaws in SharePoint, which is used by the U.S. government and companies around the world.

title: Free Shakespeare’s Central Park Home Gets an $85 Million Glow Up
summary: The rickety, beloved Delacorte Theater, built in 1962, leaked and was popular with raccoons. Now it’s a modern facility and still charmingly wild.

title: Top U.N. Court Says Countries Must Act on Climate Change
summary: The International Court of Justice called global warming an “urgent and existential threat” at a closely watched case in The Hague.

title: E.P.A. Is Said to Draft a Plan to End Its Ability to Fight Climate Change
summary: According to two people familiar with the draft, it would eliminate the bedrock scientific finding that greenhouse-gas emissions threaten human life by dangerously warming the planet.

title: What if Everything We Know About Sacagawea Is Wrong?
summary: A growing body of evidence suggests she might have survived into old age — which would entirely change the story of America’s most iconic Native forebear.

title: Meta Unveils Wristband For Controlling Computers With Hand Gestures
summary: When you write your name in the air, you can see the letters appear on your smartphone.

title: How Native Homes in New Mexico Are Tapping the Sun
summary: An Indigenous-led nonprofit group is bringing solar power to Navajo Nation and the Hopi tribe, where about 15,000 households lack access to electricity.

title: ‘The Claw Grip’: Why Are Women Always Holding Things?
summary: Known as “the claw grip” online, women are making videos about how many objects they can hold without a purse or functional pockets. What is the larger message?

title: JD Vance Claims One of Our Worst Traditions as His Own
summary: The vice president envisions a world of tiered citizenship, where entry depends on heritage and status rests on obedience.

title: No, Israel Is Not Committing Genocide in Gaza
summary: The charge isn’t only obscene. It’s also absurd.

title: Democrats in the Wilderness
summary: We look at the state of the Democratic Party.

title: Mamdani Victory Could Represent Expansion of the Left’s Influence
summary: While business leaders are anxious over the prospect of Zohran Mamdani in City Hall, the Democratic Socialists of America are contemplating how they would wield power and influence policy.

title: A Pill for Sleep Apnea Could Be on the Horizon
summary: Experts say that if the new drug gets approved, it may lead to a big shift in how we treat the condition.

title: Tesla Earnings Expected to Show Falling Profit as Car Sales Slow
summary: Elon Musk has said that robotaxis are the company’s future, but most revenue still comes from cars.
